body:
Comment 4 by **lamvak**: 
I agree on the expliciteness and I agree that it's better not to default to some
particular type, but demand an explicit declaration from the programmer.
The "cast" vs "conversion" came just from my (mis)understanding that there's actually no
data in nil to convert, so there's no much to do converting.
Anyways, my issue with the message was kind of Aristotelian - does the error stem from a
bad value (nil) or a bad type (not a slice). It's not allowed to use an untyped nil
(say, h := nil is not ok) but append does work for (properly typed) nil slice. Actually
h:= nil does produce a message about an utyped nil - maybe the message could be changed
to "have untyped nil"? I think that makes perfect sense.
